text:
Hi guys, I'm trying to connect HubSpot to a custom SAML IDP built with Samlify but I am struggling a lot and I am receiving a strange error:
```{
    "status": "error",
    "message": "Attempt to confirm settings without issuer",
    "correlationId": "6ddbf0b9-7bd3-4744-a698-b5360e9120f3"
}```
Does anyone already integrated HubSpot with a custom SAML IDP and want to share some experience? :melting_face:

Question- I have a client trying to use a property “number of patients” and they want to have a value of $122/per patient realized in a revenue report- is there something that does calculations based on a property input?? Was thinking lead score maybe?
Hi everyone, I'm obtaining certain information using deal id and some information using line id. Is there a way for me to gather all the data using just one ID?

Hello @all

Hope you are doing well

I’m working on implementing a scenario in HubSpot and was wondering if you could help me figure out whether it's possible to achieve this in HubSpot. I’ve tried implementing it but haven't been able to get it to work, and I also went through the documentation but couldn’t find a relevant solution.


*Scenario :* 
_I need to create a functionality in HubSpot for my team of 4 doctors:_

    _-Doctor A is available from 9am to 12pm_
    _-Doctor B is available from 12pm to 3pm_
    _-Doctor C is available from 3pm to 6pm_
    _-Doctor D is available from 6pm to 9pm_

_I want to create a calendar showing their availability. When a user books a meeting through the calendar link, the meeting should automatically be scheduled with the doctor who is available at that selected time._

_For example, if a user, say X, wants to book a meeting at 1pm (from 1pm to 1:30pm), they should be able to book it, and the system should automatically schedule the meeting with Doctor B (since Doctor B is available at that time)._

Hi there! Not to worry Anmol, this is quite simple.

If you add the Doctors to a team in HubSpot and get them to link their calendars with HubSpot, HubSpot will automatically detect their availability including working hours and only show available persons within that range.

I have this set up for my operations teams and it works like a dream, especially useful to consider using as well are the padding options between meetings to ensure that someone can't book a meeting within a period (for example, they can't book a meeting that starts in 5 minutes time but maybe they can book a meeting that starts in 2 hours time).
You can set up the booking form for this through Library > Meetings Scheduler. Just below the Templates in the menu.

Has documentation around this issue been updated since this post: <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/GDPR/How-to-set-ptq-gif-tracking-pixel-only-after-visitor-has/m-p/450958>?

We're currently working on our cookie policy and if we cannot remove the <http://track.HubSpot.com|track.HubSpot.com> pixel then it would be great to link to specific documentation that explains how it collects anonymous data

Here's an additional post about it: <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/Account-Settings/ptq-gif-HubSpot-Cookie/m-p/489239>

the last comment suggests that a HubSpot site cannot be GDPR compliant with this pixel automatically loading.

Is there a way to update our content policy so that it never loads?

if you are concerned with GDPR compliance please take a look at this HubSpot community post about the HubSpot tracking pixel: <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/GDPR/Blocking-the-ptq-gif-tracking-pixel-from-track-HubSpot-com-until/m-p/1052406#M1828>
<@UDJV5B73R> do you maybe know more about this?
I thought the HubSpot cookie banner handled this, but I may be wrong
wasnt there a beta at some time where one could handle cookies and  other tracking scripts at a more granular level?
Not seen anything sorry
the cookie banner does not handle that tracking pixel or related script
ah ok
<@U7SL518D6> do you maybe know more about this?

This is advice from google gemini chatbot so pinches of salt and not advice from me:

> if a user converts on a page after providing explicit consent to your cookie banner, it is generally considered acceptable to link their anonymous data to their contact information.
Again Not advice from me, I implement whatever our client tells us to do
I'm looking into the "hs_do_not_track" cookie to see if maybe that handles it. It at least suggests that no data is sent to HubSpot which I assume includes anonymous data
Does anyone know if there's any way to add custom CSS to forms built with the new editor that'll be placed on pages in a CMS other than HubSpot (eg. Wordpress)?
Are you using something like GTM, or any other tag manager? What kind of tracking you want to do?

:HubSpotheart:*Help your fellow HubSpot Developers!*:HubSpotheart:

This Slack lives and breathes by its community. If you're posting a question, take a moment and click around a few channels to see if there are any questions you can help answer. Instant karma!

I can’t speak to the legal side of it.

But the first reply on that thread is accurate based on my understanding. It’s a tracking pixel. It enables tracking page views anonymously, and I don’t think we do what the user claimed:
> It records anonymous activity which can later be linked to a speciifc user through a form submission.
Without having a cookie, the only way we could potentially link a user later to their traffic hitting the tracking cookie would be like through IP address or header info logging and even then I wouldn’t trust that enough to consider it accurate to actually link the info to the user later. So I seriously doubt we’d implement something that complicated for this scenario with such little benefit.
